column32: Iron-depleted Condition Increases Transcription of Incompatibility Group FIB plasmid Encoded Iron Acquisition Genes of Salmonella enterica
column42:
Salmonella enterica is a prevalent food pathogen worldwide. S. enterica strains harbor a number of incompatibility group (Inc) plasmids including IncFIB. IncFIB contains important genes that contribute to bacteria’s iron acquisition ability, which allows the bacteria to better persist in animal and human hosts. In this study, we aimed to determine how iron-rich (IR) and various iron-depleted (ID) conditions affect the transcription of iron acquisition and virulence genes including sitA, iutA, iucA, and enolase at different time intervals.
S. enterica wild type SE163A and a transconjugant (SE819:IncFIB) were grown in Luria-Bertani (LB) IR and LBID broth for 2, 4, and 18 hours. Ferric chloride (100µM) and bipyridyl (200µM) were added to LB broth to prepare IR and ID media, respectively. Both strains were also incubated in LBID conditions by supplementing different concentration of bipyridyl including 100, 50, 25, and 5 µM for 4 hours. Total RNA was isolated and purified from two biological replicates from each strain. cDNA was synthesized for each RNA sample and quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) using SYBR green assays were performed to determine gene expression. The primers were specifically designed to only detect the sitA, iutA, iucA, and enolase genes located in IncFIB.
All 4 genes that were grown in LBID conditions were substantially upregulated when compared to LBIR conditions. For both S. enterica strains that were grown at various LBID conditions, the 200 µM of bipyridyl had the highest transcription for all four genes and then the100 µM concentration. The other concentrations did not show any significant differences when compared to each other. Our study shows how iron-depleted conditions increase the transcription of the iron acquisition systems located in IncFIB plasmids which allows us to better understand the role of plasmid factors in the pathogenesis of Salmonella.

column32: Iron-heteroscorpionates with tunable magnetic properties
column42: Scorpionates are effective facial chelates with predictable bonding patterns involving almost every metal ion on the periodic table. Heteroscorpionate variants of this chelate-class exhibit unique asymmetry in metal-complexes. The ligand Tp’ was created in our lab (Inorg. Chem. 2011, p. 1931) through simple triazole-for-pyrazole substitution and now is made efficiently by microwave heating. The present work describes Fe(Tp’)2, a deep orange iron(II) form, whose structure of its cis-Fe(Tp’)2 isomer was confirmed by single crystal XRD. An array of methods characterized these complexes, including paramagnetic 11B NMR, Infrared, MALDI, and UV-Vis spectroscopy. The iron(II) form is characterized by unique intense MLCT in the visible region; this MLCT is red shifted in the deep purple iron(III) form. Collectively, our lab has shown M(Tp’)2 to be applicable across a range of first-row transition metals (Mn, Fe, Co, Ni). The iron(II) form also shows interesting spin-crossover (SCO, high spin/low spin equilibrium) at room temperature. Nominal HS/LS switching temperatures are unusual and increase the applicability of our compound class to more mainstream applications. Thermochemical Keq and enthalpies were determined for this SCO equilibrium. Detailed descriptions of this tunable magnetic behavior of Fe(Tp’)2 can inform efforts to use less expensive metal ions like iron for biomedical (MRI contrast agents) and high tech applications (cell phone speakers, hybrid-electric motors) that frequently rely on far more expensive and toxic rare earth metals.

column32: Biochemical characterization of chromatin environments at 3’ ends of genes as a way to uncover mechanisms of FACT complex dissociation from DNA following transcription
column36: Graham Harris, JunHyeuk Shin, Sydney Ozersky, and Andrea A. Duina
column42: To promote transcription elongation, the Facilitates Chromatin Transactions (FACT) complex, composed of the Spt16 and Pob3 proteins in yeast, works in parallel with RNA polymerase II (Pol II) by facilitating the disassembling and reassembling of nucleosomes while moving toward the 3' end of genes. In previous studies from our laboratory using the Saccharomyces cerevisiae model system, we identified a region on the side of the nucleosome, which we refer to as the ISGI (Influences Spt16-Gene Interactions) region, that is required for proper dissociation of FACT from the 3' ends of transcribed genes.  To further investigate the mechanisms that control FACT dissociation from genes, we are carrying out two mass spec-based approaches to compare the chromatin environments at 3’ ends of genes between wild-type and ISGI-mutant cells.  In the first approach, we are assaying 3’ ends of all genes by affinity purification of chromatin fragments using Rtt103, a general transcription termination factor.  For the second approach, we are characterizing the 3’ end of a single gene (GAL2) using the CRISPR-ChAP-MS methodology developed by Alan Tackett’s laboratory at UAMS.  Any differences in chromatin environments uncovered in these experiments could identify proteins or histone modifications that are normally required for Spt16 dissociation from genes.  Candidate proteins or histone modifications will be subsequently tested directly for roles in promoting Spt16-gene dissociation.

column32: Determining Protein to Protein Interactions that Regulate Helicase Activity
column37: University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences
column40: University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences
column42:
Saccharomyces cerevisiae Pif1 (scPif1) is a prototypical member of the Pif1 helicase family plays multiple vital roles in nuclear and mitochondrial DNA metabolism, such as effectively unwinding quadruplex DNA structures, maintaining telomeric DNA and reducing processivity of telomerase among other functions. Recent studies demonstrate that targeting the human enzyme is important in cancer therapy. Therefore, understanding the mechanisms of scPif1 helicase can help produced better therapeutic agents. In this study, we propose that amino acid in the protein-protein interaction domain is critical for enzyme function, and by mutating the glutamine to an alanine will results in altered enzyme activities including its affinity for DNA, ATPase activity and ability to unwind DNA structures. The glutamine at position 674 in scPif1 was mutated to alanine by site-directed mutagenesis (scPif1-E674A) and cloned into the pSUMO vector for over-expression in Escherichia coli. Using affinity chromatography and FPLC, the wild-type and mutant scPIF1proteins were purified to approximately 95% purity.  The helicase activity of scPif1 requires the hydrolysis of ATP; therefore, we assayed the DNA-dependant ATPase activities of both the recombinant wild-type and mutant scPif1. We found that scPif1-E674A has a higher enzyme activity compared to the ScPif1 wild type. We will further characterize scPif1-E674A with the DNA binding assay using single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) to determine how well scPif1-E674A interacts with DNA.
Additionally, we will utilize DNA unwinding assays to determine its ability to unwind DNA substrates in a manner similar to the wild type enzyme. Initially, we can conclude that scPif1-E674A helicase can be purified and has higher ATPase activity. These further studies will probe more deeply into the helicase activity to assist in determining the possible importance of protein-protein interactions on the DNA- and ATP-dependent activity of Pif1.

column42: Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) also known as brittle bone dysplasia, is a genetic defect causing low bone bulk, fragile bones and complications in other connective tissues. However, the leading cause of death is respiratory failure. It is estimated that at least 20,000 Americans suffer from this disease. This disease is caused by autosomal dominant mutations in COL1A1 and COL1A2 genes which encodes type I collagen or by autosomal recessive mutations in e.g. cartilage-associated protein (CRTAP) affecting post-translational modifications (PTM). Disruption of proper function of CRTAP is known to be the responsible of OI type VII. Prolyl 3-hydroxylation is essential for translation of 3-hydroxyproline to type I collagen. Prolyl-3-hydroxylase 1 (P3H1) forms a complex with CRTAP and cyclophilin B (CyPB) acting as a chaperone to 3-hydroxylate the proline residue. Surfactant protein D (SP-D) is a collagen containing lectin that helps with lung immunity and homeostasis. It is necessary to study if SP-D is affected by these PTM’s because it contains a collagen like structure. SP-D cannot be obtained easily in vivo since the quantity extraction available from mice lungs is not significant. Therefore, expression in vitro is necessary. Two plasmids are being used pCMV-DDK-C and pLenCMV containing SP-D sequence to transfect epithelial type II cell lines. Two cell lines will be used, A549 and A549 CRTAP k/o. First using A549, we will determine if the expression concentration of the SP-D is significant and if it is found intracellular or extracellular. We will analyze the PTM’s of SP-D by Flow Cytometry. Afterwards, the same process will be repeated with the A549 CRTAP k/o. The results will be compared to demonstrate the differences in concentration and/or PTM’s presented.

column32: Application of dark-field microscopy for carbon nanotubes’ toxicity analysis in mouse liver
column34: University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences
column37: University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences
column40: University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences
column42:
Steven Angtuaco1, Alena Savenka1, Todd Fite1, Mariya Khodakovskaya2, Alexei G. Basnakian1,3
1University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences, 2University of Arkansas at Little Rock, and 3Central Arkansas Veterans Healthcare System, Little Rock, AR 
Wide use of nanomaterials may eventually lead to environmental poisoning including the contamination of food. However, methods for the assessment of nanomaterial toxicity are not well developed. The current study was aimed at the development of techniques to measure toxicity of multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) in vivo. For this, male CD-1 mice were fed by oral gavage with water suspension of MWCNTs at varying doses up to 10 mg/kg/day. Twenty-four hours later, blood chemistry testing showed elevation of aspartate aminotransferase (AST), a liver injury marker, at the highest used dose. The liver damage was confirmed by the terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase dUTP nick-end labeling (TUNEL) assay. Our further analysis included the application of dark-field microscopy (DFM) for (a) the colocalization between MWCNTs and TUNEL-positive cells and (b) development of a method to quantify MWCNTs burden in liver tissue. DFM clearly showed some elevation of particulate material in the liver with occasional association with TUNEL-positive cells. DFM did not allow visualization of individual nanoparticles even at the highest magnification, and quantification of nanoparticle aggregates was not reliable due to low sensitivity of DFM at the concentration observed in the liver. Our unexpected finding was that MWCNT concentration in liver tissue could be measured instead by the decrease of mean light intensity in DFM. Increased MWCNT concentration had a direct, negative, linear correlation with mean light intensity, apparently measuring both visible aggregates and invisible particles. This DFM-based technique may become an inexpensive and precise method to determine nanoparticle burden in tissues for the purpose of toxicology assessment.

column32: Using Genomics to Design Shine-Dalgarno knockout primers in Halothiobacillus neapolitanus
Inhibition of ESKAPE Pathogens by Soil Bacteria
column42: The ESKAPE pathogens are a group of bacteria that have been identified as the leading cause of nosocomial infections throughout the world. This group of bacteria has also shown high resistance to many of the available antibiotics and most are capable of multidrug resistance. Through prior research, Ouachita Baptist University students have isolated antibiotic-producing soil bacteria shown to inhibit the growth of one or more of the ESKAPE pathogens. The goal of this research project is to extract the antibiotics produced by eighteen of these antibiotic-producing soil bacteria and screen the extracts for efficacy against the ESKAPE pathogens. The antibiotic-producing soil bacteria will be grown on the medium previously shown to promote antimicrobial production, either protein or glucose-limited M9 salts agar plates. Following a five-day incubation to allow for antimicrobial production, acetonitrile extracts will be produced from these agar plates. The acetonitrile will then be evaporated and the antimicrobial compounds resuspended in water. The efficacy of these antimicrobial mixtures will be tested against the ESKAPE pathogens using an oxidative metabolism assay with the indicator triphenyl tetrazolium chloride (TTC).  The results of these TTC assays will be presented.

column32: Investigating the clincial profile of drug-induced liver injurt amongst over 2,000 published case reports
column42: Drug-induced liver injury (DILI) is a rare but potentially fatal liver condition that is affiliated with various prescription drugs. DILI is a leading cause of drugs failing in clinical trials, being limited in use, and being withdrawn from the market. With currently used parameters, it remains challenging to predict DILI patient’s clinical course. To support the development of DILI predictive models and advance our understanding of DILI mechanisms, we are expanding the Liver Toxicity Knowledge Base with detailed clinical data included in over two thousand DILI case reports covering more than five-hundred drugs. The data incorporated will be used for statistical analysis to check correlation between DILI outcome and host factors such as race, gender, blood test results, and biopsies findings observed from liver injury caused by these drugs.

column32: The Effects of Different RNAi bacteria on Protein Aggregtaion
column34: University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences
column42: Protein aggregation occurs when misfolded proteins concentrate and it is linked with disease and problems with aging in humans.  Caenorhabditis elegans (C.elegans) is a free-living nematode that has conserved cell signaling pathways that are extremely similar to humans.  They have a short median life span of 18-20 days and a life cycle of 2.5 days and are an excellent model organism and were used in this project.  Mutant strain of C.elegans strain that has a particular mutation in the kinase domain of phosphotidyl inositol 3- kinase (PI3K, strain name mg44) was found to have a ten-fold extension to its lifespan.  We sequenced the mRNA species of the mutant and compared to wild-type organism, these mutant animals have different expression of genes.   The genes that are down regulated in longevity organism are the main focus of the project. We decided to knockdown the genes that are upregulated in wild type compared to mutant in wild-type C. elegans.  This project focuses on the effects of different RNAi bacteria on decreasing gene expression in down-regulated genes in normal C.elegans strains and seeing how that affects protein aggregation. The results could help find potential ways to lower the amount of deleterious age-associated protein aggregation.  Knock down of these genes had a negative effect on the protein aggregation for 29 of the 30 genes tested.  Only one gene decreased the aggregation. The results suggest that protein aggregation is not always associated with genes that influence life span and combination of genes are needed to impact the effects observed in long-lived mutants.

column32: Identification of genes involved in the development of nociceptive neurons in the mouse dorsal root ganglion
column42: The mouse dorsal root ganglia (DRG) are paired structures that lie adjacent to each vertebrae along the spinal cord. The DRG contain the cell bodies of a collection of sensory neurons that include nociceptors; the neurons that sense painful stimuli. In order to understand how the correct number of nociceptors are formed in the DRG during embryonic development, this study attempts to characterize part of the gene regulatory network that is required to generate these cells. One key gene that is involved in this network is the transcription factor neurogenin1 (neurog1). Neurog1 is expressed by progenitor cells in the DRG and this gene is required for the generation of nociceptors since knockout mice that lack the neurog1 gene do not produce nociceptive neurons. Because neurog1 is a transcription factor, we hypothesize that it is a key node in the gene regulatory network that produces nociceptors and that transcriptional targets of the neurog1 gene are also members of this network. To identify transcriptional targets of the neurog1 gene, we have compared the transcriptome of embryonic day 11.5 (E11.5) cervical dorsal root ganglia from wild-type and neurog1 knockout embryos. Differential gene expression analysis has identified several genes that appear to be downregulated in the knockout and therefore are potential transcriptional targets of the neurog1 gene. To confirm the differential expression of the genes identified in the transcriptome analysis, we are currently examining their mRNA expression pattern in the cervical DRG of wild-type and neurog1 knockout E11.5 embryos by in situ hybridization with complementary RNA probes. The results of this comparative analysis will be presented. column32: Unlocking the molecular mechanisms of E. coli MutS
column42: The DNA mismatch repair pathway is a system of proteins that corrects mistakes that occur during DNA replication. In E. coli, MutS initiates DNA mismatch repair via binding to the DNA mismatch. Once bound, MutS uses its ATPase activities to signal for other repair proteins to excise and correct the mismatch. MutS has been shown to have a higher binding affinity to G-T, A-C, G-G, and A-A mismatches when compared to other mismatches, C-T, A-G, T-T, and C-C, which bind at a lower affinity. Spectrophotometric ATPase assays were used to measure the ATPase activity of MutS in the presence of all eight possible DNA mismatches. From spectrophotometric ATPase assay data, a kcat value can be found that characterizes ATP reactions with MutS. Fluorescence anisotropy was used to test the binding activity of MutS by the discovery of a Kd value, which is the measurement of the protein’s binding affinity. Details like ATPase activity and binding affinity are important to understanding more about how DNA mismatch recognition works on a molecular level. Because the DNA mismatch repair system is conserved throughout nature, the DNA mismatch repair pathway of E. coli serves as a prototype for understanding DNA mismatch repair in humans. In addition, the mechanism for specific molecular recognition and signaling may be conserved across DNA metabolic pathways.

column32: A Deep Learning-based Sentiment Analysis for Drug Indication Information Retrieval
column42: Extracting computable indications, i.e. drug-disease treatment relationships, from diverse biomedical resources is the key for building a gold standard drug indication repository. The conventional natural language processing (NLP)-based strategies consist of two major steps: identification of indication description from free text and disease named-entity recognition (NER) with ontologies. However, the identification of indication description is mostly achieved through human annotations, which is time-consuming and label intensive. In this study, we developed a deep learning-based sentiment analysis for indication description extraction. First, we curated a benchmark drug indication information pool consisting of 7745 sentences (4076 indication description sentences and 3669 negative control sentences) from “Indications and Usage Section” in 36108 FDA approved prescription labeling documents. Second, the biomedical-based word embeddings were developed by employing whole FDA approved drug labeling documents using word2vec. Third, a deep learning-based sentiment analysis was implemented for distinguishing the positive and negative indication description sentences using word2vec-based word embeddings with a Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) model. Finally, we evaluated the model performance with a 50-time Monte Carlo cross validation (MCCV) and external indication resources including Wiki-drug, RxList, and clinicaltrial.gov, which generated a promising performance comparable to state-of-art methodologies. In summary, the proposed deep learning-based sentiment analysis framework could be an effective strategies for indication information retrieval, which could be potentially utilized for drug repositioning verification and the drug review process.

column32: Investigating DNA Polymerase κ Function as a Barrier to Replication Catastrophe and Genomic Instability in Breast Cancer
column37: University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences
column40: University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences
column42: Cancer cells experience sustained replication stress from oncogenic activity that results in abnormally high amounts of DNA damage and activation of the replication stress response (RSR). Prolonged or widespread stalling of the replisome leaves DNA vulnerable to catastrophic damage. Consequently, cancer cells activate mechanisms, such as translesion synthesis (TLS), that can resolve replication intermediates arising from stress at the fork. TLS requires the action of Y-family DNA polymerases that are able to bypass DNA lesions. TLS polymerase kappa (pol κ) plays a vital role in bypassing certain barriers to fork progression, as well as in the protection of stalled forks from degradation by nucleases. Previous studies have implicated pol κ in the resolution of fork stress in cancers like glioblastoma, but the role of pol κ in breast cancer (BrCa) has yet to be established. BRCA1 mutated BrCa cells are homologous recombination deficient (HRD), which makes these cells more reliant on alternative RSR mechanisms for survival. We hypothesize that pol κ acts as a barrier to DNA replication catastrophe, genomic instability, and cell death in BrCa cells and that this role is amplified in HRD BrCa. We will evaluate the importance of pol κ to genome maintenance in BrCa by measuring changes in replication fork dynamics, genome stability/DNA damage formation, and proliferation/viability due to pharmacological inhibition or CRISPR-Cas9-mediated knock-out of pol κ in both BRCA1 WT and BRCA1 mutant BrCa cell lines. We predict that pol κ loss will increase replication defects and BrCa cell sensitivity to genotoxic agents, especially in BRCA1 mutant cells. Additionally, we expect pol κ depletion in BRCA1-deficient cells to cause chromosomal instability in response to Wee1 checkpoint inhibition. Completion of this study will improve our understanding of the RSR in BrCa and may help us develop new strategies to increase breast cancer treatment success.

column32: Safety and Risk Assessment Associated with Nanocrystal Drug (Zileuton) Formulation
column42: Nanocrystal drug (ND) formulation is an emerging technology in the field of medicine that helps to improve the solubility and bioavailability of oral drugs, especially in poorly soluble Biopharmaceutical Classification System (BCS) II and IV drugs for clinical applications. Advantages of ND include lower drug concentrations, higher solubility, increased bioavailability, earlier-onset of bioactivity, increased adhesive capacity in the gastrointestinal-tract and prolonged-time in circulation. Despites these beneficial effects, the safety of nanocrystal drugs is still highly debated and of great concern. The formulation for producing ND alters the biophysical and biochemical properties of ND in comparison to the same drugs in their traditional micro-sized form. As a result, we expect to see variation in the reactivity of ND in the intestinal tissue. We tested our hypothesis using formulated Zileuton ND (poorly soluble BCS-II drug) to evaluate intestinal permeability and assess the immunotoxicity of ND. Human intestinal tissues (ileum and colon) were obtained from CHTN network. Biopsy punches of intestinal tissues were incubated with ND, physical mixture (Zileuton, Sucralose, Kollidon and DowfaxA21), or Kollidon in a 24 transwell plate for 24 hours at increasing concentrations (0.1, 1, 10, 100 and 1000 µg/ml). Tissue was homogenized to isolate RNA and proteins. Cytokines levels were measured using a 48-plex cytokine kit obtained from Bio-Rad. The cytokine data revealed that Zileuton ND decreases IL-5 secretion only in ileal tissue at low concentrations. The results also revealed that 0.1 µg/ml and 1µg/ml treated ileal tissue exhibited higher levels of several proinflammatory cytokines (IL-6, HGF, Eotoxin, NGF and IFN-gamma, IFN-alpha) compared to 1000 µg/ml treated tissue of ND. In contrast, few cytokine levels were higher only at higher ND concentrations. A detailed profile for intestinal permeability related gene expression will also be discussed in detail.

column32: Characterization of Stream Quality of five Ouachita River Tributaries Utilizing Macrobenthic Species and Fish Populations.
column42: The Ouachita River originates in west central Arkansas and exits the state in southcentral Arkansas near El Dorado.  There are many tributaries that make up the Ouachita River through its Arkansas journey.  Five of these tributaries are located in Clark County and will selected for this research. Basic in situ water quality parameters were measured and the riparian zone was characterized at each sample site.  The five streams selected were Decieper/Little Deceiper Creek, Mill Creek, DeRoche Creek, Saline Bayou, and Tupelo Creek. Macrobenthic and fish surveys were conducted at two sites (upper and lower) on each creek except Saline Bayou and Tupelo Creek which included only one site each.  Streams will be characterized using the tolerant and intolerant species. Potential impacts of these streams include runoff from agriculture, municipal runoff from the city of Arkadelphia, and miscellaneous anthropomorphic sources from town.  Presence of intolerant species indicates less impact while finding only tolerant species indicates potential disturbance that warrants further investigation.

column32: Staphylococcus aureus Exhibits a Modified Growth Pattern in Media Supplemented with Porcine Blood
column42:
Staphylococcus aureus, a gram-positive bacterium, is primarily the etiologic agent for menstrual toxic shock syndrome (TSS), an infection that is often associated with the menstrual cycle of women and especially those who use tampons with high absorbency.  Toxic shock syndrome is an example of a condition resulting from toxemia caused by S. aureus that is facilitated primarily by toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1).  TSST-1 is a superantigen promoting an exaggerated response by the human immune system and can potentially lead to septic shock and death.
Antibiotic resistance in S. aureus remains a major concern thus, it is important to understand the environmental conditions that are conducive for growth and toxin production of S. aureus during the course of a menstrual cycle.  In an effort to simulate the conditions of menstruation and evaluate the growth behavior of S. aureus, two prototypic TSS-causing S. aureus strains, MN8 and FRI-1169, were grown in tryptic soy broth (TSB) enriched with 36% porcine blood.  Growth was analyzed by viable cell count in 2-hour increments for the first 12 hours and every 24 hours up to seven days thereafter. These cell counts were then compared to the cell counts of S. aureus grown in TSB alone.  The data revealed an altered growth pattern for both MN8 and FRI-1169 in TSB containing blood in comparison to growth in TSB alone.  Strains MN8 and FRI-1169 exhibited a 10- and 100-fold decline, respectively, in viability within the first two hours when grown in the presence of blood. The strains were then able to recover to levels comparable to growth in TSB alone.  Currently, experiments are being conducted to determine if the production of virulence factors, specifically TSST-1, are affected when S. aureus is grown in blood.

column32: “Perceived Motor Skill Competency as related to the Development of Locomotor and Object Control Skills in Young Children Ages Three through Five.” Lucianne Burner, Dr. Scott Doig
column42:
Central Arkansas Summer Undergraduate Research Symposium
“Perceived Motor Skill Competency as related to the Development of Locomotor and Object Control Skills in Young Children Ages Three through Five.” 
Lucianne Burner
Dr. Scott Doig
Arkansas State University, Jonesboro

Perceived motor skill competency plays an important role in physical activity levels of children and adolescents. Perceived motor skill competency is related to lower levels of physical activity, which can further limit the ability to develop motor skills. The goal of this study was to determine if perceived motor skill competency at ages three through five relate to the ability of children to develop locomotor and object control skills regardless of amount of physical education experience. Physical education was provided to 102 children (ages three through five) at one of three levels, five days per week, three days per week, or no intervention. All students completed a perceived motor skill competency assessment and Test of Gross Motor Development (TGMD) before starting the intervention. After the intervention students completed a second TGMD. A significant relationship was found between the amount of physical education intervention time received and the ability to develop object control (F= 3.38, P < 0.05, η2 = 0.09) and locomotor skills (F= 16.68, P < 0.05, η2 = 0.33).  No significant relationship was found between perceived motor skill competency and object control and locomotor skills. Findings suggest that early physical education intervention can facilitate development of locomotor and object control skills in children despite potential negative effects of low perceived motor skill competence scores.

column32: Characterization of Alcaligenes faecalis SORT-26 Genome
column42: ESKAPE pathogens are a group of antibiotic-resistant bacteria mounting the threat of antibiotic-resistance in the clinical setting. SORT-26 has been noted to produce antimicrobial compound(s) when grown on glucose-starvation M9 salts agar which inhibit the growth of the ESKAPE pathogens Acinetobacter baumannii, Enterobacter aerogenes, and Klebsiella pneumoniae. Metabolic testing and phylogenetic analysis via 16S rRNA gene sequencing suggests that SORT-26 is a novel, antibiotic-producing strain of the Gram-negative bacterium Alcaligenes faecalis. Whole genome sequencing conducted using Pacific Biosciences long-read technology and assembled at MOgene produced a 4,083,727 bp genome in a single contig, while the taxonomic threshold program JSpecies indicated average nucleotide identity (ANIm) values from 86.7% to 89.58% against the most similar Alcaligenes faecalis genomes, suggesting that SORT-26 is a previously-unreported strain of this species.  Initial genome characterization was conducted with Quast and BUSCO, revealing 59.11% GC and 96.7% of the benchmarking universal single-copy orthologs (BUSCOs) expected for gammaproteobacteria.  The auto-annotation pipeline Prokka returned a suggested annotation of 3678 coding sequences (CDs), 59 tRNA genes, 9 rRNA genes, and 1 tmRNA gene.  Additional genomic analyses for terminators, CRISPR-Cas genes,and orthologous protein sequence families will be conducted, and the results of these analyses will be presented.

column32: Studies of a possible pathway involving Malic Enzyme 1 (ME1) and NADPH Oxidases (NOX/DUOX) in a mouse model of intestinal cancer
column34: University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences
column37: University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences
column39: Rosalia C.M Simmen and Frank A. Simmen
column40: University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences
column42:
Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third ranked cause of cancer-associated deaths in the United States.  CRC is characterized by metabolic and redox pathway dysregulation within tumors.  Our goal was to investigate a potential metabolic and redox pathway involving Malic Enzyme 1 (ME1) coupled to one or more members of the NOX/DUOX family.  ME1 catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of S-malate to pyruvate and generates reduced NADP (NADPH) used, in part, for lipid and cholesterol biosynthesis.  We hypothesized that cytosolic NADPH generated by ME1 is also used by the NOX/DUOX family of proteins to generate increased levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS), the latter then promoting growth of intestinal tumors.  Our laboratory previously developed a new mouse model of intestinal cancer by crossing mice overexpressing ME1 in the intestinal mucosa (ME1-Tg mice) with ApcMin/+ mice that bear a mutation in the Adenomatous Polyposis Coli (Apc) gene.  We found an increase in number and size of intestinal tumors in ApcMin/+/ME1-Tg mice, compared to ApcMin/+ littermates.  In the present work, small and large intestines from these same mice were subject to immunohistochemistry (IHC) for NOX1, NOX4 and DUOX2 (three members of the NOX/DUOX protein family hypothesized to be highly expressed in normal intestines and their tumors).  Adenomas were highlighted by IHC for β-catenin.  IHC for NOX1 revealed staining in the uppermost regions of the villi of the normal appearing intestinal mucosa. NOX4 IHC stained the smooth muscle layers of the small intestines.  Neither NOX1 nor NOX4 IHC preferentially stained the adenomas.  DUOX2 IHC signal, in contrast, was localized to the proliferative cells of the crypts, and in the submucosa and adenomas (sporadic staining).  The data suggest physiological roles for NOX1, NOX4 and DUOX2 in intestinal physiology, and support a possible linkage of ME1 and DUOX2 in redox regulation of intestinal adenoma growth.

column32: Effects of a Nutrition/Physical Activity Intervention in Improving Children’s BMI-for-Age Percentiles
column42: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) report that 18.5% (13.7 million) U.S. children and adolescents age 2-19 years are overweight or obese. Obesity rates are 13.9% in 2- to 5-year-olds, 18.4% in 6- to 11-year-olds, and 20.6% in 12- to 19-year-olds.  Hispanic children (25.8%) and non-Hispanic black children (22%) have higher obesity prevalence than non-Hispanic white children (14.1%). column32: Investigating the Presence of BPA in Infant Oral Hygiene Products Using Fluorescence Spectroscopy

Bisphenol-A (BPA) is a chemical found in hard plastics. BPA is an endocrine disruptor as it binds to estrogen receptors. This is linked to negative health effects such as cardiovascular disease and developmental issues. Infants and young children are more at risk to these effects because their endocrine systems are not fully developed. For this project, toothbrushes were investigated to determine if they contained BPA. BPA is a fluorescent compound with an excitation wavelength of 278 nm and an emission wavelength of 304 nm, so a FS-5 spectrofluorometer from Edinburgh Instruments was used to determine the presence of  BPA in each sample. 
	Each toothbrush was placed in 100 mL of a 1:1 methanol:water solution at room temperature. A 5-mL aliquot of the solution was taken at time intervals ranging from 5 minutes to 1 week after the toothbrush was placed in the solution. Each sample was run in the spectrofluorometer in duplicate, where the emission and excitation intensities were reviewed and recorded. These values were compared to a BPA calibration curve in order to determine the concentration of BPA leached into the solution from the toothbrushes. 
After determining which toothbrushes had traces of BPA, a similar method was utilized to investigate where the bulk of the BPA was located within the toothbrush. The bristles were removed from the BPA-containing toothbrushes. The bristles and the head of each toothbrush were then placed separately into 100-mL solutions of 1:1 methanol:water and analyzed following the protocol described above.

Same significance patterns were not observed in the subclinical seizures.  PACs between theta and gamma oscillations in the seizure period were higher in comparison with pre- and post-ictal segments in clinical seizures. column32: Evaluation of Gliovascular Coupling in a Transgenic Rat Model of Alzheimer’s Disease
column35: Columbia University in the City of New York
column42: As the sixth leading cause of death in the U.S. and most common cause of dementia, Alzheimer’s disease (AD) places a significant burden on the healthcare system. No cure has been developed for this disease, and it can often be difficult to diagnose and treat due to the clinical manifestations occurring late during pathological progression. This project explored gliovascular development in a transgenic rat model (Tg) to characterize the neural response to AD pathogenesis. We predicted proliferation of astrocytic activity at older ages, corresponding with augmented immune responses to AD progression. Here, a transgenic rat model (Tg) was used that overexpressed the mutated genes responsible for familial AD; double-labeling with Lycopersicon esculentum Lectin and Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein allowed examination of the gliovasculature of brain tissues of these animals. Control rats demonstrated healthy vasculature, with negligible astrocytic activation at all ages examined. At 6 months in the Tg group, cortical astrocytic activity was minimal, while hippocampal astrocytic activity was notable in regions containing plaques intertwined with vessels. At 9 months in the Tg group, astrocytic activity augmented in both regions, with extended astrocytic endfeet localized around vessels and plaques. Within this age group, neurovasculature deteriorated, indicated by thinned and torn vessels in the hippocampus and cortex. At 16 months of age, astrocytic activity proliferated throughout cortical and hippocampal regions in the Tg group, corresponding to areas near toxic Aβ plaque deposits. Vessels in this age group showed the most degeneration of all Tg groups, indicating progressive ischemic qualities of neurovasculature in the regions affected by AD pathology. Overall, these findings indicate a direct relationship between the temporal progression of the disease and stimulated astrocytic astrocytic activity which affects vasculature in areas most affected by AD pathology.

column42: During meiosis, homologous recombination plays two important roles.  First, it is responsible for proper disjunction of homologous chromosomes from each other at the first division and second, it produces genetic diversity in the resulting gametes. Homologous recombination occurs more frequently at specific DNA sequence motifs known as hotspots.  Understanding the mechanisms controlling hotspot recombination is important as errors in the positioning and frequency of recombination events can give rise to aneuploidy, which is the leading cause of miscarriages and birth defects.  Using nucleosome scanning assays in the model organism Schizosaccharomyces pombe, our laboratory showed that chromatin remodeling occurs at five different hotspot motifs but not at a corresponding control.  By combining a mass spectrometry approach with classical genetics, we identified proteins involved in this process at the well-studied hotspot ade6-M26. This current research focuses on whether these proteins are also required at four additional hotspots that have been placed in the same genomic location. These hotspots are known as CCAAT, Oligo-C, 4095, and 4156. To do this, recombination levels are determined in the presence and absence of each of these putative regulatory proteins. The deletion mutant that exhibits reduced recombination frequency pinpoints a role for the corresponding protein in regulating hotspot recombination.

column32: The role of CYP2B6 in sertraline-induced toxicity in hepatic cells
column42: Sertraline is an antidepressant commonly used to manage mental health symptoms relating to depression, anxiety disorders, and obsessive-compulsive disorder. The use of sertraline has been associated with rare but severe hepatotoxicity; however, the mechanism remains unclear. Previous research has demonstrated that ER stress, mitochondria impairment, and apoptosis are involved in sertraline-induced cytotoxicity. It has also been demonstrated that sertraline is mainly metabolized by cytochrome P450 (CYP) 2B6. In this in vitro study, we used our established CYP2B6-overexpressed HepG2 cell line to investigate the role of CYP2B6 in sertraline-induced cytotoxicity. These findings indicate that CYP2B6 plays a role in the metabolic detoxification of sertraline by preventing DNA damage. This work contributes to our overall understanding of the role that metabolic enzymes play in sertraline-induced hepatotoxicity.

column32: Multispectral Imaging to Investigate Tumor Immune Responses
column42: Despite early successes in clinical trials and huge research investments, little is known about what is actually happening between tumor and immune cells in solid tumors. However, the combination of multi-marker immunohistochemistry (IHC) with multispectral imagining with complex per-cell quantitation methodologies has opened the door for more complex immune profiling of tumors and has implications in a range of other diseases where immune cells play a role. Specifically, we proposed to utilize multiplexed immunofluorescence (Opal® Multiplex Fluorescent IHC, Akoya Biosciences) coupled with multispectral imaging and advanced image analysis (inForm®, Akoya Biosciences) to evaluate immune response in formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tissue blocks from patients diagnosed with different types of breast cancer. First, we developed protocols from the Opal® Multiplex Fluorescent IHC Kit to establish a multiplexed indirect immunofluorescence approach using FFPE blocks retrieved from the pathology archives. The kit allowed the simultaneous use of six standard unlabeled primary antibodies and detection with Opal reactive fluorophores that covalently label the epitope. After labeling is complete, antibodies are removed in a manner that did not disrupt the Opal fluorescence signal, permitting the next target to be detected without fear of antibody cross reactivity. Next, we will develop the advanced analysis workflow using the inForm® analysis software. The workflow will involve spectrally un-mixing and quantifying fluorescent activity intensity of each fluorophore. Once unmixed, inForm® will be used to segment tumor and stromal tissues, to identify and quantify cell types, assess fluorophore overlap, and provide information about individual cell phenotypes and spatial relationships. By having a panel of 6 different antibodies already assessed, it will be simple to substitute a new marker of interest in its place to compare a different immune response.

column32: Implementing RNAi and CRISPR/Cas9 to Investigate DNA Repair Genes in Bdelloid Rotifers
column42: Genomic DNA regularly becomes damaged by numerous ways, including desiccation, radiation exposure, and during recombination in cell division. Fortunately, cells have DNA repair pathways that seek out and correct damage. The bdelloid rotifer Adineta vaga is an excellent model organisms to study DNA repair because it has a highly efficient DNA repair system. The mechanisms of DNA repair in these aquatic invertebrates are unknown. This project explores using RNA interference (RNAi) and CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing as tools to investigate the function of DNA repair genes: MSH6 and MLH1 in bdelloid rotifers. Two methods of RNAi were explored. For the “feeding method,” bdelloids were fed strains of E. coli that express dsRNA copies of the MLH1. For the “soaking method,” double stranded RNA (dsRNA) copies of MSH6 were synthesized, and bdelloids were transfected with these molecules of MSH6. The expectation was that ingested or transfected dsRNA would induce RNAi in bdelloid rotifers. Real-time PCR followed to quantify expression of the target gene and determine if the RNAi knockdown was successful. CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing was done to mutate DNA repair genes. For utilizing CRISPR/Cas9, a single guide RNA that targets MLH1 was synthesized and used in a Cas9 in vitro cleavage assay to determine its ability to cut the target sequence. The guide RNA was then combined with Cas9, and these ribonucleoprotein complexes were electroporated into bdelloids. Mutation detection using T7 endonuclease was then done to identify alterations to the gene sequence. Gene knockdowns using RNAi and gene mutations using CRISPR/Cas9 will provide a reverse genetics approach to identify genes that have a role in bdelloid DNA repair. This could enhance our understanding of similar mechanisms in traditional model systems, which could have implications for biomedical research.

column32: Effects of Temperature on the Release of Bisphenol-A from Toothbrushes
column42: Bisphenol-A (BPA), is a chemical found in many hard plastics. BPA has the capability of binding to estrogen receptors in the body, which can lead to various adverse effects. These concerning effects range from cardiovascular disease to developmental issues. As a result, BPA is regulated in many infant products; however, infant and children’s toothbrushes are not regulated. Previous studies in our lab have shown that some infant oral hygiene products release differing amounts of BPA into solvent (1:1 methanol/water) at room temperature over time. In this experiment, toothbrushes that were previously confirmed to contain BPA were analyzed to determine the effect of temperature on the amount of BPA released from the toothbrushes into the solution. Since the toothbrush is used in the oral cavity, which is not at room temperature, it is important to see how an increase in temperature affects the amount of BPA released. Each toothbrush was placed into a 150-mL beaker that contained 1:1 methanol/water solution. Each beaker was then placed into a water bath at 23˚ C, 30˚ C, or 37˚ C. Aliquots of solution (5 mL) were removed at time intervals ranging from 5 minutes to 48 hours, and an Edinburgh Instruments FS5 Spectrofluorometer was used to measure the fluorescence intensity of BPA in the solutions. These values were compared to a standard calibration curve of known concentrations of BPA, and the concentration of BPA in the solutions at each time point was determined. A graph for each temperature was then constructed, plotting the concentration of BPA released vs. the time interval. This aided in determining which temperature had a greater effect on the release of BPA from the toothbrush into solution.

column32: Eficiency of Burkholderia Cepacia Detection at Low CFU in Different Mediums Using Culture-Based, PCR, and Flow Cytometry Methods
column42: The Burkholderia cepacia complex (BCC) is a group of opportunistic human pathogens that infect patients with immunocompromised systems. This project focused on the detection of Burkholderia cepacia in three types of solutions at low concentrations of Colony Forming Units (CFU) of the bacteria. We compared the efficiency of culture-based methods, real-time PCR, digital droplet PCR (ddPCR) and flow cytometry. BCC was diluted to the appropriate CFU (1, 10, 100, and 1000 CFU/ml) in autoclaved nuclease-free water, 0.01% Chlorohexidine Antiseptic, or 0.13% Benzalkonium Chloride Antiseptic, and five replicates were used per concentration for a total of 20 tests per strain. Five 10 μl samples of each serial dilution of 20 BCC strains were directly pipetted onto 1/10x TSA or 1/10x TSB using the drop plate method. In parallel, DNA prepared by boiling lysis and 10 μl preparations were real-time and ddPCR assays. Last, 10μl of each dilution in 330μl PBS reagent and 650μl nuclease-free water were analyzed five times using a flow cytometer. The detection efficiency of the culture-based methods were significantly (p < 0.05) lower than those of the two PCR assays and the flow cytometry.

column32: The Effects of Friction on the Release of BPA from Infant Toothbrushes

Bisphenol A (BPA) is a compound which mimics estrogen, allowing BPA to bind to estrogen receptors in the body in place of estrogen. This mistaken binding results in BPA acting as an agonist and antagonist for certain mechanisms in the body, which can result in early development, reproductive issues, and cancer. Though BPA has been omitted in several infant products, there is no regulation on the amount of BPA that can be present in infant toothbrushes. The excitation and emission intensities of the samples were collected and compared to a calibration curve to determine the concentration of BPA present in each sample. Data were correlated with samples that were collected without brushing to determine if the friction affected the amount of BPA leached from the toothbrushes.

Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third ranked cause of cancer-associated deaths in the United States.  CRC is characterized by metabolic and redox pathway dysregulation within tumors.  Our goal was to investigate a potential metabolic and redox pathway involving Malic Enzyme 1 (ME1) coupled to one or more members of the NOX/DUOX family.  ME1 catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of S-malate to pyruvate and generates reduced NADP (NADPH) used, in part, for lipid and cholesterol biosynthesis.  We hypothesized that cytosolic NADPH generated by ME1 is also used by the NOX/DUOX family of proteins to generate increased levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS), the latter then promoting growth of intestinal tumors.  Our laboratory previously developed a new mouse model of intestinal cancer by crossing mice overexpressing ME1 in the intestinal mucosa (ME1-Tg mice) with ApcMin/+ mice that bear a mutation in the Adenomatous Polyposis Coli (Apc) gene. DUOX2 IHC signal, in contrast, was localized to the proliferative cells of the crypts, and in the submucosa and adenomas (sporadic staining).  The data suggest physiological roles for NOX1, NOX4 and DUOX2 in intestinal physiology, and support a possible linkage of ME1 and DUOX2 in redox regulation of intestinal adenoma growth.

column32: Determining Human DNA Helicase B involvement in Protecting Stalled Replication Forks from Nucleolytic Degradation
column42: Every day our DNA is damaged by endogenous and exogenous agents resulting in DNA lesions that, if not repaired properly, can lead to the formation of cancerous cells and ageing. To avoid these outcomes, our cells have developed the DNA damage response (DDR) for detection and repair of DNA damage. One component of this protective mechanism is replication fork reversal in response to replication stress to prevent the fork from progressing across the DNA lesions and allow time for repair. When the replication fork reverses, the two new synthesized strands anneal resulting in a four way junction. If the regressed arm of the four way junction, which resembles a one-ended double strand break, is not protected, the nascent strands can be degraded by nucleases resulting in an unstable genome. Previous studies have found that BRAC2, RAD51, and other proteins involved in homologous recombination are required to protect the regressed arm against the degradation of the nascent strand. Prior studies have also shown that human DNA helicase B (HELB) inhibits end resection during homologous recombination. With this understanding, our goal was to determine if HELB is also involved in the protection of DNA at a stalled fork. Using human retina pigmented epithelial (RPE-1) cells, we knocked down HELB using siRNA, treated the cells with the DNA damaging agent hydroxyurea (HU), and used the fiber labeling technique to analyze DNA replication. Through this technique, we will be able to get a greater understanding of the cell’s ability to protect stalled replication forks in the absence of HELB.

column32: Response of Dictyostelium discoideum to Varying Wavelengths of Light and Perception of Gravity
column42: Dictyostelium discoideum is known as a model organism due to its unique life cycle. When food is present the Dictyostelium lives as a unicellular amoeba. However, when food becomes scarce and the cell starves, aggregation of many unicellular amoebae is seen as they form a motile, multicellular “slug”. This slug responds to stimuli in its environment, particularly light, and moves to find a more suitable position upon which it forms a fruiting body for spore dispersion. While the means by which the slug moves is not fully understood, response to cAMP waves and varying intensity and quality of light as well as gravity are believed to be the most plausible reasons. In this experiment, slug movement of Dictyostelium was examined under the effects of red and blue light, as well as antigravity conditions which were produced by a clinostat. Blue light was observed to have the most effect on slug movement, while red light had the least effect on slug movement. Results also exhibit that gravity does affect slug movement. Slugs in stationary (non-gravity manipulated) plates showed affinity toward light, but slugs on a clinostat exposed to the same wavelength of light generally showed a higher affinity for that light. Slugs grown in the dark showed a preference for gravitaxis, indicating gravity has an effect on slug movement, but the slug’s response to light appears preferential to gravity.

column32: Nickel-nickel dimers structurally similar to common nickel(II)-scorpionates
column42: An entirely new class of nickel-nickel dimers will be described, in which two nickel(II) centers are held close together (3.2 Å) by bridging pyrazolide ions. These anionic [Cl-Ni(mu-pz)3Ni-Cl-] dimers are synthesized by direct reaction of the corresponding sodium pyrazolide and tetrachloronickelate(II) ion in DMF. Each is stable in the solid state as its PPh4+ salt. This general approach is effective for a variety of bridging groups: pyrazole, 3,5-dimethylpyrazole, 3,4,5-trimethylpyrazole, and 4-chloro-3,5-dimethylpyrazole. Each of these dimer salts was characterized by MALDI-TOF MS and UV-visible electronic spectroscopy.  The [Cl-Ni(-Me2pz)3Ni-Cl-] salt was characterized by single crystal XRD, confirming for the first time the formation of this novel structure.  The similarity of the nickel(II) environment in this dimer and the well-characterized Tp*NiCl monomer invites contrasts and comparisons.  For example, the new dimer environment makes nickel(II) unusually unresponsive to Lewis basic DMF molecules, where Tp*NiCl binds this solvent immediately and reversibly. Room temperature magnetic measurements suggest each dimer possesses two independent high spin (S = 1) nickel(II) centers, as if the dimer represents two Tp*NiCl units sharing a bridge through the Tp* chelate. Electronic spectra of these dimers show the tell-tale signature of previously reported monomeric Tp*NiX (X = Cl, Br, I; all S = 1), reinforcing the model of these dimers as conjoined Tp*NiCl units. While their novel architecture makes these nickel-nickel dimers interesting on their own, these discrete high spin complexes (S ~ 2) can also be molecular magnets, well-defined magnetic centers that can be incorporated into nano-scale devices.

“Epigenetic Pathways of Radiation Induced Cognitive Injury in a Pediatric Murine Model” 
Grace Guzman, Annick De Loose MS, Antiño Allen, PhD, and Analiz Rodriguez M.D, PhD
University of Arkansas at Little Rock, University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences

Advances in cancer treatment have increased the survival rate of brain cancer patients. However, multiple studies have provided evidence that 50-90% of survivors that live more than 6 months experience cognitive dysfunction following radiotherapy. Radiation alters specific structures and regions of the brain including the hippocampus, white matter, and prefrontal cortex that are associated with memory loss, decline in verbal ability, and learning difficulties. Yet, there is minimal knowledge of what epigenetic mechanisms cause these radiation-induced cognitive injuries in the developing brain. MicroRNAs (miRNAs), non-coding RNAs that regulate gene silencing by targeting mRNA, could be a critical component in radiation-induced cognitive injuries. The aim of the current study is to assess whether the miRNA levels are different in juvenile mice exposed to whole brain irradiation (20Gy) in comparison to control mice (n=10 per group). One month following irradiation, the mice were tested for cognitive performance using the Y-maze and the Morris Water Maze. The behavioral findings of the sham and radiated mice were compared to miRNA profiles. Our behavioral data show that radiation impairs spatial memory but does not impair short-term memory or spatial learning.  Total RNA (both mRNA and miRNA) was isolated from mice hippocampi.  RNA integrity numbers were all greater than 6.0.  Total RNA is currently undergoing next generation sequencing to evaluate the transcriptome and over 400 miRNAs.  Our preliminary data confirms that hippocampal function is altered following irradiation of juvenile mice.  We aim to delineate epigenetic factors in the hippocampus that are potentially reversible.

column32: Biophysical Characterization of E. coli MutS Using Absorption and Fluorescence Spectroscopies
column42: With a base pair mismatch occurring approximately once every cell division, it is vital for an efficient DNA repair system to identify and correct DNA mismatches in order for the cell to avoid detrimental mutations. The DNA mismatch repair system consists of a system of proteins that work in collaboration with each other to recognize and repair mismatches that occur during DNA replication. The E. coli mismatch recognition protein, MutS, functions by recognizing existing mismatches and communicating with downstream proteins to initiate the repair process. Fluorescence anisotropy allowed for the characterization of the mismatch binding activity of MutS. The dissociation constant Kd, which shows the binding affinity of MutS to specific mismatches, can be obtained from this data. The ATPase activity of MutS in the presence of each base-base mismatch was observed with a spectrophotometric malachite green assay. With this information, the kcat can be determined to characterize the ATPase activity of MutS. Cancer, Huntington’s disease, and many other neurodegenerative diseases thrive when MutS homologs in the human mismatch repair system do not function as they should. More research into understanding the mechanics of MutS and mismatch repair will provide information to slow or prevent the progression of such diseases by allowing for the promotion or inhibition of MutS homologs and other similar proteins.

column32: Graph Database Utility in A Medical Setting
column42:
In medical settings, a relational database is commonly used to hold data. However, in large scale databases, a relational database can get rather complex and hard to understand for non-database experts – for a large medical facility handling thousands of patients, databases are composed of hundreds of separate tables. Additionally, to extract data from a relational database, researchers or data scientists must have deep knowledge of the database schema and a database management language. While this method works, my research demonstrates a different approach to store data, in the form of graph databases. A graph database is more visually intuitive, and its emphasis and ability to visualize groups of nodes and the relationships between them leads to a data-driven discovery approach, versus the traditional hypothesis-driven discovery [1]. A researcher using a graph database can simply open a graph database visualization tool and observe individual nodes and their connections to other nodes. This can lead to the discovery of connections and relationships between data points that a researcher may not have even considered using just the hypothesis-driven approach. On top of that, a graph database is still able to support the traditional methods of research – a researcher can query a graph database to receive contextualized and relevant data, much like he or she could do with relational databases.
The goal of this study is to discover specific advantages of graph databases over relational databases in a medical setting, as well as create a basic implementation of a graph database using Neo4J [2], coupled with an application that allows users to access the graph database and query it with ease. This three-pronged approach will demonstrate the effectiveness of graph databases in representing the complex relationships between data points generated in medical facilities, as well as demonstrate the benefits a transition to graph database models could generate.

“Elucidating the Antioxidant Activity of Stilbenoid-Rich Extracts from Hairy Root Cultures of Peanut”
Emily Hendrix,1* Patrick Roberto,1 and, Fabricio Medina-Bolivar1,2
1Department of Biological Sciences, 2Arkansas Biosciences Institute, Arkansas State University

Overproduction of free radicals can induce cellular impairment by reacting with amino acids, lipids and proteins. This phenomenon, known as oxidative stress, results in several diseases in humans including cancer, neurodegeneration, cardiovascular disorders, and obesity.  Dietary antioxidants such as the stilbenoid resveratrol (RSV) have been shown to reduce free radicals in vitro and in vivo. However, the antioxidant capacity of extracts enriched with RSV and related stilbenoids have been largely unexplored.  To this end, the aim of this project was to characterize the antioxidant activity of stilbenoid-rich extracts in vitro using the DPPH (2,2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl) assay combined with HPLC (high performance liquid chromatography). To produce the stilbenoid-rich extracts, hairy root cultures of peanut cultivar line Hull 3A were treated with methyl-β-cyclodextrin, methyl jasmonate, hydrogen peroxide, and magnesium chloride for 168 hours. RSV and the prenylated stilbenoid arachidin-1 (A1), arachidin-2 (A2), arachidin-3 (A3), and arachidin-5 (A5) were detected in the ethyl acetate extract of the culture medium by HPLC. Upon reaction with DPPH, the HPLC peak areas of A1, A3, and A5 decreased significantly, suggesting that these compounds reacted with DPPH. However, RSV and A2 apparently did not react with DPPH. Ongoing studies focus on elucidating the antioxidant capacity of different fractions of the extract containing either RSV or prenylated stilbenoids. Our result suggests that the stilbenoid composition of the extract influences the antioxidant activity. Extracts enriched with select stilbenoids may provide an alternative to RSV as dietary supplements for the prevention of diseases in humans.

column32: Analysis of MutS-DNA interactions with fluorescence anisotropy
column42: The DNA mismatch repair pathway is a highly conserved system of proteins that work together to identify and excise regions of replicated DNA containing base-base mismatches and short insertion/deletion loops. In the first step of the mismatch repair process, the MutS family of proteins recognize and bind to base-base mismatches and signal to activate downstream repair proteins, although the details of these mechanisms are debated in the literature. The DNA mismatch recognition protein E. coli MutS has high affinity for G/T, A/C, G/G, and A/A mismatches, which the mismatch repair system repairs with high efficiency. A/G, C/T, T/T, and C/C mismatches are repaired with lower efficiency. In order to understand the molecular mechanisms of DNA mismatch recognition, fluorescence anisotropy measurements were used to assess the binding characteristics of MutS to eight mismatch types. A Fluoromax-4 fluorometer was used to measure the fluorescence anisotropy of emissions from TAMRA-labeled DNA as the concentration of MutS protein was varied. Origin was used to fit a 1:1 binding equation curve to ensemble anisotropy data, which allowed for the dissociation constant to be determined. The binding affinity measurements agreed with what is known from the literature, indicating that the anisotropy analysis method can be relied upon for generating reproducible protein association data and for providing insights into the mechanics of protein-DNA interactions. Since MutS-mismatch binding affinity correlates with mismatch repair efficiency, the data will be used in comparing the binding kinetics of MutS with efficiently repaired mismatches to the binding kinetics of MutS with less efficiently repaired mismatches. Clarifying the mechanism of mismatch recognition in E. coli is important because it is possible that the process is conserved across nature.

column42: More than 5 million patients suffer from lymphedema, an accumulation of lymph fluid in the tissues, as a complication of breast-cancer treatment. The National Cancer Institute reported that there were more than 15.5 million Americans with a history of cancer and more than 3.5 million breast cancer survivors in 2016. Chemotherapy is indicated for early and advanced or metastatic breast cancers. While such regimens are effective, chemotherapy can lead to severe cognitive impairments that persist long after treatment in as many as 75% of survivors. Impairment commonly referred to as chemobrain is characterized by symptoms such as confusion, memory deficits, and difficulty concentrating. The goal of the current study was to identify late effects of Doxorubicin, Cyclophosphamide, and Paclitaxel (AC-T) on cognition and characterize molecular pathways in the hippocampus are affected after treatment. “The Development of Tools and Methods for the Genetic Manipulation of Borrelia duttonii” 
LeAnn McFadden1*, Tyler Ratliff2, Clay Litteken2, and Jon S. Blevins2                                                                           
 1University of Arkansas at Little Rock, 2University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences 
Vector-borne spirochetes of the genus Borrelia utilize ticks and the human body louse as vectors. By traveling through the bite of a colonized vector, a subset of these bacteria can be transmitted to humans and initiate the disease known as relapsing fever. Studies into relapsing fever are few in number, despite the disease being identified in the early 20th century. Relapsing fever are divided into two groups; New World relapsing fever Borrelia are found in the Americas and Old World relapsing fever Borrelia are common in Africa.  Of the limited research, the focus is mainly on New World relapsing fever Borrelia species. However, Old World relapsing fever Borrelia are responsible for a higher percentage of the world’s relapsing fever cases. The scarcity of molecular biology and genetic resources suitable for Old World relapsing fever Borrelia results in insufficient understanding of the spirochetes’ lifecycle, pathogenesis, and interaction within its host. To address this discrepancy concerning the lack of appropriate procedures for the genetic manipulation of Old World relapsing fever Borrelia, various tools and methods for the genetic manipulation of Borrelia duttonii, an Old World relapsing fever spirochete, will be developed. The set of genetic tools constructed for Borrelia duttonii included the creation of a B. duttonii specific shuttle vector, the development of a site-specific integration construct that targets the B. duttonii pl165 linear plasmid, and the inactivation of the B. duttonii p66 gene. We have also tested existing Borrelia electroporation methods to determine whether they are suitable for transformation of B. duttonii.

column32: A comparison of sleep spindle density in sleep following ictal activity and in sleep following periods of no ictal activity
column34: University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences
column42: Sleep spindles have been shown to be fundamental in memory consolidation, maintenance of sleep continuity, as well as being indicators of stress resilience and intelligence. Because of these important functions of sleep spindles, the effects that neurological disorders have on them have been of special interest to neurobiologists. Studies conducted on patients with epilepsy have examined the generalized effect of epilepsy on sleep spindles. The studies have shown a general decrease in both the density and frequency of sleep spindles in patients with epilepsy. However, there is a lack of research on the effect of ictal activity on the subsequent night’s sleep spindle density. The purpose of this study is to compare the density of sleep spindles of patients with epilepsy in sleep following ictal activity and in sleep without ictal activity. Scalp electroencephalogram (EEG) data were provided by the University of Arkansas for the Medical Sciences. Using the programs MATLAB and Brainstorm the data were processed and converted into a .mat file type. This conversion was necessary to enable scoring and detection of sleep spindles by the program Visbrain. We used patients who had twenty four hour periods containing at least one ictal event and who also had a twenty four hour period without an ictal event. Using a band pass filter (low pass 1 Hz, High pass 70 Hz), a notch filter (at 60 Hz), and the program Visbrain, the sleep stages of the patients were processed and scored. Visbrain was then used to calculate the density of sleep spindles in NREM sleep. Our findings demonstrate a negative correlation between ictal activity and sleep spindle density when compared to periods with no ictal activity.  The effect is most pronounced within the first hour of post-ictal sleep with a trend back to baseline after the first hour.

column32: Evaluating the Effect of Mutant EGFR on GPIT Subunit Expression in Glioblastoma Multiforme
column42: The glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor is a lipid and glycan modification post-translationally added to the C-terminus of substrate proteins in the endoplasmic reticulum by GPI transamidase (GPIT), which consists of five subunits. Two of these subunits, PIG-U and GPAA1, have previously been characterized as oncogenes in bladder cancer and breast cancer, respectively. Elevated plasma levels of GPI-anchored proteins in glioma patients have been documented relative to non-malignant controls. Additionally, GPAA1 overexpression has previously been linked to physical association of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) with GPIT, resulting in phosphorylation of the subunits PIG-T and PIG-U. However, the relationship between GPIT and EGFR is not well characterized, particularly in GBM. EGFRvIII, a variant EGFR that is commonly seen in GBM patients, has a truncated extracellular region that allows it to constitutively phosphorylate substrates without a signal ligand binding. It is suspected that this may lead to the upregulation of GPIT subunits, and thus an increase in GPI-anchored proteins. Based on the previously established relationship between EGFR and GPIT, this unregulated constitutive phosphorylation may also cause an increase in GPIT activation in patients with EGFRvIII. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the expression levels of GPIT subunits in GBM with and without the EGFRvIII mutation. These studies will increase our understanding of the oncogenic relationship between GPIT and EGFR and the therapeutic potential for GPIT inhibition in GBM.

column32: Genetic Dissection of High Fat Diet Induced Changes in the mRNA Expression of Genes Involved in Intestinal Barrier Integrity
column42: A high fat diet (HFD) can alter the gut microbiota and intestinal barrier integrity, which can result in multiple health risks. This study is conducted to assess the contributions of genetic background and diets on the gastrointestinal health, as measured by changes in the mRNA expression of genes involved in the intestinal epithelial permeability using collaborative cross (CC) mice. The CC mouse model is a state-of-art mouse strain that represents a genetic diversity similar to the human population. Six weeks old CC mice were fed either high-fat diet (42% Kcal from milk fat high in palmitic acid, 0.2% of total cholesterol, and >30% high sucrose (HFD; experimental group)) or low-fat and reduced sucrose diet (control group) for 12 weeks. We had previously identified certain strains of CC mice which harbor a distinct population of microbes due to HFD. RNA was extracted from banked ileal tissue obtained from ten different strains of CC mouse.  The RNA samples were then treated with DNAse and converted into cDNA to assess the mRNA expression level of 84 different genes known to be involved in the epithelial cell integrity. The CT values were recorded, and the data was analyzed using Qiagen PCR Array Data Analysis Tool. The preliminary data indicates that the susceptible male mice (CC mice where microbiota was affected due to HFD) showed higher number of up-regulated genes. Few of these genes are Claudins, which may assist in controlling the permeability of the paracellular barrier between tight junctions. The resistant male mice (CC mice where microbiota was not affected due to HFD) showed down-regulation of several genes such as Occludins, which also assist in controlling the permeability of the paracellular barrier. This in turn indicates looser tight junctions and more permeability between the cells.

column32: Investigations on possible roles for DNA sequences in promoting dissociation of the FACT complex from the 3’ ends of genes following transcription
column36: Sam Byrd, Brianna Hoyt, Daniel Habenicht, Heather Prowse, Sydney Ozersky, Jennifer A. Harper, Alex Crocker, Claire E. Turkal, Lauren Joseph, and Andrea A. Duina
column42: In eukaryotic cells, histone chaperones can manipulate chromatin environments to facilitate a variety of processes that occur on DNA, including gene transcription. FACT (FAcilitates Chromatin Transactions) is a highly conserved histone chaperone complex that plays important roles during the initiation and elongation phases of transcription.  In yeast, FACT is composed of two proteins, Spt16 and Pob3, which can interact directly with nucleosomes with the assistance of the HMG-box protein Nhp6.  Previous research from our laboratory has identified a region on the nucleosome – which we refer to as the ISGI (Influences Spt16-Gene Interactions) region – that is required for proper dissociation of FACT from the 3’ ends of genes at the end of the transcription process. To further investigate the mechanisms that control FACT dissociation from genes, we are carrying out studies to determine possible roles for DNA sequences in this process.  To determine if DNA sequences play a role in FACT dissociation from genes, we have generated fourteen internal deletions within the 3’ end of the constitutively expressed yeast gene PMA1 and assessed their effects on Spt16 dissociation.  These studies identified a region within the 3’ end of PMA1 required for normal dissociation of Spt16 from chromatin.  To determine whether this region controls Spt16 dissociation indirectly by impairing RNA Polymerase II (Pol II) termination, we are currently assessing the effects of deletion of this region on Pol II dissociation.  We are also assessing the effects of the other thirteen internal deletions on Pol II-gene dissociation.  Together, these studies will provide insights into possible direct or indirect roles for specific DNA sequences in ensuring proper Spt16 dissociation from genes following the transcription process.

column42: As the human lifespan has lengthened, along with the addition of more technology and awareness of anatomical function, neurodegenerative disorders have grown in prevalence among the elderly population.Parkinson’s disease is a multisystem neurodegenerative disorder characterized by cognitive decline and motor dysfunction, which ultimately leads to a loss of independence and death. column32: Effect of ADU-Ph, a Small Organic Molecule on the Ras-Related Protein Cdc42
column42: The Ras superfamily is comprised of several protein subfamilies of small GTPases; and upon its activation, this family is known to interact with effector domains leading to a cascade of protein-protein interactions. The mutational activation or the over-expression of the Ras superfamily has been observed in a number of human cancer; which over the years, efforts have been focused on the inhibition of the Ras superfamily proteins that lead to cancer. The protein Cell division cycle 42 (Cdc42), is a member of the Rho GTPase family, a Ras subfamily member, which acts as a molecular switch and signals multicellular pathways to influence a variety of biological responses such as motility, morphology, and gene expression. The activation of Cdc42 is regulated by guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs) by the exchange of GDP and GTP; and deactivated by GTPase activating proteins (GAPs) which turn the protein off by stimulating GTP hydrolysis. The deregulation of Cdc42 affects the natural activity of cells, leading to the development of many pathological disorders in humans such as cancer. It has been observed that the over-expression of this protein has been related to play a critical role in non-small lung cancer, breast cancer, and melanoma just to name a few.  The focus of this study is to analyze small organic molecule-protein interactions aiming to find a molecule which inhibits the oncogenic behavior of Cdc42. The small molecule ADU-Ph will be tested on Cdc42 and Cdc42 T35A to find whether it has any affinity for binding the protein and/or if it has any effect on the protein regulation and their functions.
